title: How to Do a Title Page in MLA Format

steps.title: Write the title about one third of the way down the page.
steps.content: Write the title about one third of the way down the page. The title should follow normal title capitalization standards: the first letter of each word should be capitalized with the exception of very short words such as articles or prepositions (e.g. the, and, of, or, a, an, in, to, for). Note that the very first word of the title should be capitalized, regardless of what kind of word it is. Do not punctuate your title. It does not need to have quotation marks around it, it should not be underlined, and it should not be in italics. If, however, there is a quotation or a reference to a longer work in your title, that should be punctuated accordingly. For example, "To Be or Not to Be:" An Analysis of Hamlet's Soliloquy contains a quote, while An Analysis of Inaction in Shakespeare's Hamlet contains the title of the play, which should be italicized.

steps.title: Leave 2-3 lines, then write your name.
steps.content: Leave 2-3 lines, then write your name. Be sure to include your first and last name. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Write the course or class information.
steps.content: Write the course or class information. You may want to include the section number as well as the name of the course. [2] X Trustworthy Source Purdue Online Writing Lab Trusted resource for writing and citation guidelines Go to source

steps.title: Write the instructor's name on the next line.
steps.content: Write the instructor's name on the next line. Be sure to include the appropriate title, particularly if your instructor has a doctorate. [3] X Research source For example, Dr. Sarah Smith or Dr. Smith.

steps.title: Write the date on the next line.
steps.content: Write the date on the next line. MLA format generally calls for a European style date, with the day, then the month, then the year. [4] X Research source For example, 2 February 2014.
